bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, November 6, 1940

div1.p: Hench describes the Lazear memorial event at Washington and Jefferson College. He writes about how glad Mabel Lazear was to learn the truth about her husband's sacrifice. Hench believes that the Camp Lazear memorial and preservation of Building No. 1 will be carried out successfully.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, November 6, 1940
div1.p:
I leave tomorrow for a series of medical meetings, and have been so
busy preparing for them that I have not had time to write you since my return
from the Washington and Jefferson affair.

The dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building was very fine. The
ceremony was most dignified and impressive, and the building is a beautiful
one. There was quite a crowd there, and my talk at the banquet Saturday evening
was most sympathetically received. Three relatives of Dr. Lazear were present
and were so interested in all that I had to say. Mrs. Lazear was unable to be
there herself, but I had written her of the affair and sent her a copy of my
paper. She was simply delighted to know what had been discovered. She did
not know that any of what you told me and one could appreciate how delighted
she was to know that her husband's sacrifice was in behalf of science and not
due to an accidental “blunder”.

I think the enclosed clipping will interest you, and when I return
from the medical meetings and catch my breath, I will write you further as to
my plans for memorializing the true site of Camp Lazear and Building No. 1.
I plan to publish my Washington talk which, however, will be merely the first
of several papers on the affair, and I will certainly send you as many reprints
of the Washington talk and others as you may wish. Doubtless, some friends
of your father's will be most interest in knowing what you have told me.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
